issue.title: Parse old versions of sdf files without warnings

content.raw:
Ideally, each model in the model database would have a version at the oldest compatibility level, with new versions added manually to take advantage of new features.

If this was the case, a warning could be given when the latest version of a model is not able to be open for compatibility reasons, but it seems like a bookkeeping headache to have to update the ground plane even if the old version is fully compatible.

It may add a bit to the runtime to do the conversions, though. I'd like to hear other people's opinions.
content.html:
Ideally, each model in the model database would have a version at the oldest compatibility level, with new versions added manually to take advantage of new features.

If this was the case, a warning could be given when the latest version of a model is not able to be open for compatibility reasons, but it seems like a bookkeeping headache to have to update the ground plane even if the old version is fully compatible.

It may add a bit to the runtime to do the conversions, though. I'd like to hear other people's opinions.

issue.title: Parse old versions of sdf files without warnings

content.raw:
There are a few things to consider:

1. In general we don't want to promote the use of older code. It'll be more difficult to debug problems. People will also use the older files as templates from which to build new models.

1. Changing SDF versions does not happen that often, so updating the models is not a major problem.

1. ThePropShop will handle auto-conversion for us in the near future.
content.html:
There are a few things to consider:

  1. In general we don't want to promote the use of older code. It'll be more difficult to debug problems. People will also use the older files as templates from which to build new models.

  2. Changing SDF versions does not happen that often, so updating the models is not a major problem.

  3. ThePropShop will handle auto-conversion for us in the near future.

issue.title: Parse old versions of sdf files without warnings

content.raw:
1. I agree we shouldn't promote the use of older code, but if a file is unaffected by a change in sdf version I don't think we should have to touch it. For example, in the change from 1.3 -> 1.4, we renamed three elements in the `<world><physics>` block
(for example `update_rate` to `real_time_update_rate`, see
[here](#!/osrf/sdformat/src/778bf6bc844dbff80ed6131627be1cc1618747c5/sdf/1.4/1_3.convert?at=default)).
This affects world files but not model files.
I think it causes unnecessary work and significant duplication of code to duplicate all the model files just to bump the version number. When there are actual changes, then yes we should update the model file, but only in specific cases (I'm planning to update the polaris models to sdf 1.5 for example to take advantage of the joint axis frame fix).

2. Assuming that SDF versions don't happen that often is an argument against making it easy to change things, which slows down development. I'm not hoping to release a new sdf version every week, but I think it's worth streamlining the process.

3. Curve ball here. Not sure whether anything I said will be relevant for long.
content.html:
1. I agree we shouldn't promote the use of older code, but if a file is unaffected by a change in sdf version I don't think we should have to touch it. For example, in the change from 1.3 -> 1.4, we renamed three elements in the <world><physics> block (for example update_rate to real_time_update_rate, see here). This affects world files but not model files. I think it causes unnecessary work and significant duplication of code to duplicate all the model files just to bump the version number. When there are actual changes, then yes we should update the model file, but only in specific cases (I'm planning to update the polaris models to sdf 1.5 for example to take advantage of the joint axis frame fix).

  2. Assuming that SDF versions don't happen that often is an argument against making it easy to change things, which slows down development. I'm not hoping to release a new sdf version every week, but I think it's worth streamlining the process.

  3. Curve ball here. Not sure whether anything I said will be relevant for long.

issue.title: Parse old versions of sdf files without warnings

content.raw:
Multiple versions with different styles is not great path to go down. The intent of the conversion script was to make it easy to migrate old version to the most recent. Automatic conversion is nice to have, but is not something that should be the assumed behavior. 

All the different versions, and how they interact, may be clear to us, but it will be confusing to everyone else. An upgrade path, with the assumption that someone should upgrade, is the a practice that is common and familiar to most people.

The SDF version number (this is different from the libsdformat version number) only changes when a conversion script is required. Ideally, this should happen infrequently. A file format only becomes useful if it remains stable for a long period of time. There have been many changes in the past, but major breaking changes should be coming to an end. 

We should assume the extra burden of managing SDF versioning rather than have the user deal with it when they use our tools.
content.html:
Multiple versions with different styles is not great path to go down. The intent of the conversion script was to make it easy to migrate old version to the most recent. Automatic conversion is nice to have, but is not something that should be the assumed behavior.

All the different versions, and how they interact, may be clear to us, but it will be confusing to everyone else. An upgrade path, with the assumption that someone should upgrade, is the a practice that is common and familiar to most people.

The SDF version number (this is different from the libsdformat version number) only changes when a conversion script is required. Ideally, this should happen infrequently. A file format only becomes useful if it remains stable for a long period of time. There have been many changes in the past, but major breaking changes should be coming to an end.

We should assume the extra burden of managing SDF versioning rather than have the user deal with it when they use our tools.

issue.title: Parse old versions of sdf files without warnings

content.raw: Probably my biggest issue is duplication of code / model files. It takes more work and is more likely to have bugs when we maintain multiple versions of the same file.
content.html: Probably my biggest issue is duplication of code / model files. It takes more work and is more likely to have bugs when we maintain multiple versions of the same file.

issue.title: Parse old versions of sdf files without warnings

content.raw: I discussed this with @nkoenig and we're going to keep the warnings to encourage use of the latest version of sdformat.
content.html: I discussed this with @nkoenig and we're going to keep the warnings to encourage use of the latest version of sdformat.
